Market Implied Inflation Signal

Market-implied inflation signal: tracking investor expectations for future inflation.

As of Unknown

Gemini Summary

Signal Summary:

  • The Market-Implied Inflation Expectations (MIIE) signal is currently STABLE as of 2025-12-31, with a composite z-score of 0.038.
  • Current market expectations for 5-Year Forward Inflation and 10-Year Breakeven are 2.29% and 2.25% respectively.
  • This indicates moderate inflation expectations, but recent momentum suggests a softening trend compared to prior months.

Key Dynamics:

  • While both 5Y and 10Y breakeven levels remain slightly above their historical averages, recent momentum is negative.
  • The 5Y Forward Inflation Expectation's 3-month annualised z-score is -0.628, and its YoY z-score is -0.374.
  • Similarly, the 10Y Breakeven's 3-month annualised z-score is -0.674, indicating a clear deceleration in short-term expectations (1).
  • These negative momentum components are offsetting the moderate level readings, maintaining the STABLE regime.

Macro Relevance:

  • This signal directly informs the market's forward inflation expectations dimension of the macro environment.
  • It typically behaves as a mid-cycle signal, reacting to shifts in monetary policy expectations and economic growth outlooks.
  • When combined, a STABLE MIIE with negative momentum may foreshadow disinflationary pressures ahead of lagging indicators like CPI.

Data & References:

  • T5YIE (5-Year Forward Inflation Expectation Rate) — FRED, 2025-12-31.
  • T10YIE (10-Year Breakeven Inflation Rate) — FRED, 2025-12-31.
  • The negative contributions from `t5yie_ann3m_z` and `t10yie_ann3m_z` most influenced the current STABLE state and momentum.
  • Additional public datasets: CPI (Consumer Price Index), Fed Funds Rate expectations.

References

  1. [Source: Methodology]
